Abstract

Canopy stomatal uptake of $\mathsf { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } }$ (NO, $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 } ^ { \cdot \cdot }$ ， $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ by three mature urban plantations (of Schima superba, Eucalyptus citriodora and Acacia auriculaeformis) were studied using the sap flow-based approach under free atmospheric conditions. The annual mean concentration for NO, $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ ， $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ were 18.17, 58.05, 12.76 and $4 2 . 3 6 ~ { \mu \mathrm { g } } { \cdot } \mathrm { m } ^ { - 3 }$ , respectively. The atmospheric concentration exhibited a spring or winter maximum for NO, $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ ， whereas the concentration maxima for $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ occurred in the autumn. Despite the daytime mean canopy stomatal conductance $( G _ { \mathrm { C } } )$ being positively related with the photosynthetically active radiation $( P A R )$ and negatively with the vapour pressure deficit $( V P D )$ , the maximal daytime mean $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ did not appear when the $P A R$ was at its highest level or the $V P D$ was at its lowest level because a positive correlation was noted between the daytime mean $P A R$ and VPD （ $( P { < } 0 . 0 0 1 )$ under field conditions. The $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ value was regulated by the cooperation of the $P A R$ and VPD. When analysing the respective effect of the $P A R$ or $V P D$ on $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ separately, a positive logarithmical correlation was noted between the daytime mean $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ and $P A R$ as the following equation: $( P { \ < } 0 . 0 1 )$ ，and the daytime mean $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ was negatively logarithmically correlated with the $V P D$ ： $( P < 0 . 0 0 1 )$ ). The daytime mean $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ declined with decreases in the soil water content (SWC） under similar meteorological condition. Differences in the seasonal pattern of the canopy stomatal conductance and atmospheric concentrations led to a differentiated peak flux. The flux for NO, $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ exhibited a spring maximum, whereas the flux maxima for $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ appeared in the autumn or summer. The annual accumulative stomatal flux for NO, $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ ， $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ was 100.19±3.76, 510.68±24.78, 748.59±52.81 and $1 5 1 . 9 8 { \pm } 9 . 3 3 \$ $\mathrm { m g } { \cdot } \mathrm { m } ^ { - 2 } { \cdot } \mathbf { a } ^ { - 1 }$ , respectively. When we focus on the foliar uptake of trace gases, the effect of these gases on the vegetation in turn should be considered, particularly for regions with serious air pollution problems. These trace gases had not yet reached injury levels, except for $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ . Flux-based measurements were better suited for evaluating the risk of $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ damage to vegetation than the exposure-based method.

1.Introduction

Tropospheric concentrations of trace chemicals (such as $\mathsf { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } }$ ， $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 } ^ { \cdot }$ ）inthe atmosphere have increased significantly within the last century (Low et al.，2012; Richter et al.，2005; Seinfeld and Pandis, 2012; Smith et al.， 2011). One important potential consequence of this change is alteration to the climate (Ramanathan et al., 1985). Studies of the radiative forcing of these chemically reactive species showed that $\mathsf { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } }$ emissions have a global cooling effect because they indirectly remove $\mathrm { C H } _ { 4 }$ by increasing the abundance of OH radicals and produce aerosols that cool the atmosphere (Schulze et al., 2O1O). Sulphur dioxide is a principal precursor of sulphate aerosols, which may affect climate directly by reflecting solar radiation into space and indirectly by changing the reflective properties of clouds and their lifetimes (Karl and Trenberth，2003)． Tropospheric ozone $( \mathrm { O } _ { 3 } )$ ，an important greenhouse gas，is responsible for direct radiative forcing $( 0 . 3 5 { - } 0 . 3 7 \ \mathrm { W { \cdot } m ^ { - 2 } } )$ (Ainsworth et al., 2012). Apart from their influences on the climate, trace chemicals are also important atmospheric constituents responsible for air pollution. Atmospheric nitrogen oxides contribute to photochemical smog, the formation of acid rain precursors and the destruction of the ozone in the stratosphere (Bowman, 1992). Additionally, $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ is the major gaseous precursor of acidic precipitation (Vahedpour and Zolfaghari, 2011). Because of the negative influences that these trace gases display on the environment, regions with a high contamination level must reduce these gas concentrations to an acceptable level by focusing on controlling the source of air pollutants and on the removal of existing pollutants (Yang et al., 2008).

In recent years, foliar uptake of trace gases has attracted interest (Eichert and Fernandez, 2O12). Trace gases enter the leaves predominantly through the stomata, and moreover, the stomatal uptake is a direct addition to plant metabolism and could potentially more readily influence plant growth depending on the concentration and plant species (Eichert and Fernandez, 2012; Sparks, 2009). In addition, a critical level for the stomatal uptake is noted, beyond which the leaf detoxification systems are unable to cope with the stress induced by gas molecules (Josipovic et al.， 2010; Karlsson et al., 20o4). Thus, quantifying the stomatal fluxes of these pollutant gases is important. During the last few decades， several micrometeorological methods for quantifying trace gas exchange between the terrestrial ecosystem and atmosphere have been developed including the eddy covariance technique, aerodynamic profile method and Bowen ratio-energy balance method (Grunhage et al., 2000). However, separating the stomatal deposition component from the overall flux using these methods remained difficult (Sparks, 2Oo9). Additionally, dry deposition models are used to analyse trace gas exchange between the phytosphere and atmosphere. Despite the fact that stomatal uptake can be modelled, modelling methods display a common difficulty of estimating the physiological functions of plants. Because plant species differ considerably in their response to environmental conditions and because the effects of important environmental factors such as soil moisture are difficult to model realistically, stomatal conductance estimates are frequently inaccurate (Pleim et al, 1999).Within the frame of such studies,appropriate methods to estimate the longterm and continuous aboveground stomatal uptake of gases by vegetation under natural atmospheric conditions must be developed (Kostner et al., 2008).

The above outlined mechanistic shortcomings can be overcome through the sap flow approach, as recently suggested and demonstrated by Wieser et al. (2003), Matyssek et al. (2004), Nunn et al. (2007), Kostner et al. (2008) and Wang et al. (2012). The sap flow-based methodology contributes a new quality of flux data, significantly improving our understanding of biospheric aspects of trace-gas fluxes into tall vegetation (Kostner et al.， 2Oo8). Trace gas flux at the canopy scale can be obtained from the concentration gradient between the atmosphere and the intercellular space,and the canopy stomatal conductance for trace gases derived from the conductance for water vapour (because transpiration and trace gas flux are coupled through the activity of the stomata) (Wieser et al.， 20o6). Additionally, the stand transpiration and the synchronous meteorological data provide the basis for the calculation of the canopy stomatal conductance for water vapour. The stand transpiration can be estimated through the sap flow measurements combined with stand characteristics.

Rapid economic development during the past two decades has already led to regional air pollution problems over the Pearl River Delta (PRD） in South China (Zheng et al.， 2O09). Studies have reported that high levels of ozone have been observed in the PRD region over the past few decades (Liu et al., 2O08; Wang et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2Oo8), and the ozone background concentrations increased by an average rate of 0.55 ppbv:yr-1 during 1994-2007 (Wang et al., 2009). $\mathsf { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } }$ emissions also exhibited increasing trends during 2000-2009 (Lu et al.， 2013). Although the regional monitoring network data indicate a reduction of atmospheric $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ （204号 concentration because of the decrease in the $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ emissions (Wang et al.， 2013), the （20 $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ concentration in the PRD region is still substantially higher than those reported for large cities in Europe and North America (Wan et al., 2O11). Urban vegetation is generally considered to be eective in mitigating various air pollution problems (Jim and Chen, 2008; Setalä et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2008; Yin et al., 2011). In the present study， we investigated stomatal uptake of $\mathrm { \Delta N O _ { X } }$ ， $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ by mature urban plantations (S. superba, E. citriodora and $A$ . auriculaeformis) using the sap flowbased approach in Guangzhou City which is located in the central region of PRD, China. The main objectives are the following: (1） to analyze seasonal and annual patterns of the $\mathsf { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } }$ $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ concentrations, the canopy stomatal conductance and the fluxes of these trace gases between the vegetation canopy and the atmosphere; (2) to elucidate the relationship between the canopy stomatal conductance and environmental factors and the conditions under which the daytime mean canopy stomatal conductance $( G _ { \mathrm { C } } )$ reaches a maximum; (3） to quantify the annual accumulative stomatal uptake of trace gases; (4） to evaluate whether the current situation reached a certain contamination degree using the exposure-based approach(De Vries et al.， 200o; Tao and Feng 2O0O) and the flux-based approach (Simpson et al., 2007).

2.3.Sap flow measurements

In total,21,15 and 15 sample trees of different diameter classes were selected in the S. superba, E. citriodora and A. auriculaeformis plantations, respectively, for sap flow measurement. 3.2. Canopy stomatal conductance and its relationship with environmental factors

Daytime mean $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ (from 8:00 to 18:00) under the condition of $V P D { \geq } 0 . 2 ~ \mathrm { k P a }$ varied with ambient environmental conditions over the annual course (Figure 3). At the seasonal time scale, the daytime mean $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ in summer was significantly higher than those in other seasons in S. superba and $E$ citriodora plantations $( P { < } 0 . 0 5 )$ , as shown in Figure 4. For A. auriculaeformis, the highest value was observed in the spring followed by the summer, whereas the values in autumn and winter were relatively lower. text: 3.3. Fluxes of trace gases

The annual pattern for the daytime mean flux of the four studied trace gases is shown in Figure 10. The combination of the canopy stomatal conductance and the atmospheric concentrations produces fluxes of trace gases. Thus, differences in the seasonal pattern of the canopy stomatal conductance and atmospheric concentrations may result in differentiated peak fluxes. The daytime mean flux for NO, $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ exhibited a spring maximum for the three tree species,whereas the daytime mean flux maxima for $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ occurred in the autumn or summer (Figure 11).

That the flux is not synchronous with the canopy stomatal conductance (or the deposition velocity） or the atmospheric concentration has been demonstrated by previous studies. Zimmermann et al. (2Oo6) observed that the flux maxima occurred during October to December for both $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ in the eastern Erzgebirge whereas the deposition velocity showed the highest values from May to September when using a modelling method. Wieser et al. (2006) reported that the $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ uptake in a pine forest in Tenerife showed no clear seasonal trend although the ambient ozone concentration showed an obvious seasonal change when using the identical method. This asynchronism can be attributed to the coincidence of higher $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ levels with the time when trees suffered from water stresses and the stomata were closed.

text: 3.4. Effects of trace gases on the urban tree canopy

These four trace gases are potential risk constituents in the atmosphere that may exert negative effects on vegetation. We use the exposure-based approach or flux-based approach to assess whether the present levels of these gases had reached a contamination degree, namely the corresponding threshold value. With consideration to the relative sensitivity of different tree species, the $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ critical level for a broadleaf forest is assumed to be an annual average of $2 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { g } } { \cdot } { \mathrm { m } } ^ { - 3 }$ according to the report of Tao and Feng (2OoO). In this present study, the annual average $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ concentration was $1 2 . 7 7 \ \mu \mathrm { g } \cdot \mathrm { m } ^ { - 3 }$ ，nearly half of the critical level， indicating that the present $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ （204号 concentration had not yet reached the injury level. For $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ ， the calculated annual average concentration $( 5 8 . 0 6 ~ \mu \mathrm { g } \cdot \mathrm { m } ^ { - 3 } )$ ） exceeded the critical concentration levels for $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ $( 3 0 ~ \mu \mathrm { g } \cdot \mathrm { m } ^ { - 3 } )$ (De Vries et al.，20oo), implying a possibility of $\mathbf { N O } _ { 2 }$ damage to vegetation.Nevertheless,whether the present $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ concentration negatively affected the vegetation requires further study because of the diverse sensitivity of different plants to $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ (Kohno et al., 2005).

Two types of approaches have been previously used when assessing the risk of $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ damage to vegetation. One method is the AOTX index (accumulated exposure over threshold of X ppb). The second method is the $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } Y }$ approach (accumulated stomatal flux over threshold of $\mathrm { Y \ n m o l { \cdot } m ^ { - 2 } { \cdot } s ^ { - 1 } }$ ), this approach entails an estimate of the amount of $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ entering vegetation via the leaf stoma (Simpson et al., 2OO7). We calculated the typical AOT40 and $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } } 1 . 6$ . The AOT40 of the wet season (from Apr. to Sep.) at our study site was 13.13 ppm:h (Table 4), exceeding the current European critical level for ozone effects on forest trees $( 5 \ \mathrm { p p m \cdot h } )$ ）（UNECE 2004) and even the previous critical level $( 1 0 \ \mathrm { p p m { \cdot h } ) }$ (Kärenlampi et al., 1996). In contrast, the $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } } 1 . 6$ values for all of the studied species were below $4 \mathrm { m m o l } { \cdot } \mathrm { m } ^ { - 2 }$ ,the current flux based critical level for $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ effects on trees (UNECE 2Oo4). The situation during the dry season was similar to that in the wet season,i.e.,with an AOT4O above the critical level and an $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } } 1 . 6$ below the critical level. Although the estimation of the flux was excluded when （204号 $V P D { < } 0 . 2 \ \mathrm { k P a }$ , the calculated $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } } 1 . 6$ is credible because the possibility that the flux was above 1.6 nmol $\mathbf { m } ^ { - 2 } { \cdot } \mathbf { s } ^ { - 1 }$ when $V P D { < } 0 . 2$ kPa was small due to the low transpiration， stomatal conductance and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ concentration (The generation of $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ is closely related to the solar radiation intensity(Tu et al.，2007) which is usually low
when the VPD is low).

Only the $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ molecules that enter the leaves through the stomata are harmful to plants (Fuhrer, 20oO). Although the atmospheric $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ concentration was relatively high based on the AOT40 value, the $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ had not yet reached the injury level according to the $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } } 1 . 6$ value. Therefore, the performance of the stomata, which is associated with the environmental factors and tree physiological properties, must be considered when analyzing $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ damage to vegetation. Namely, the flux-based measurement is better suited for evaluating the risk of $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ impacts on trees than the exposure-based method, as demonstrated in previous studies (Gerosa et al.， 2008; Wang et al.， 2012). In addition, despite the fact that the AOT4O in the dry season was higher than that in the wet season, the $F _ { 0 3 }$ and $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } } 1 . 6$ exhibited a higher value in the wet season. The relatively lower $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ and the high $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ concentration not coinciding with the higher stomatal conductance during the dry season were responsible for this inconsistency.

text: 4． Conclusions

In this study, we investigated the stomatal uptake of $\mathsf { N O } _ { \mathrm { X } }$ ， $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ by mature urban plantations (S. superba,E. citriodora and $A$ . auriculaeformis) using the sap flow-based approach in Guangzhou in the PRD region, China. At this study site, the atmospheric concentration exhibited a spring or winter maximum for NO, $\mathbf { N O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ ， whereas the concentration maxima for $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ occurred in the autumn. The canopy stomatal conductance was jointly regulated by the PAR and VPD.Apart from the PAR and VPD, the SWC affects the physiological activity of plants. The daytime mean $G _ { \mathrm { C } }$ declined with the reduction of the SWC under similar meteorological condition. A comprehensive understanding of the influence pattern of environmental factors on the canopy stomatal conductance could provide references for enhancing the tree canopy capacity to remove trace gases.

Differences in the seasonal pattern of canopy stomatal conductance and atmospheric concentrations led to a differentiated peak flux. The flux for NO, $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ exhibited a spring maximum, whereas the flux maxima for $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ appeared in the autumn or summer. The annual accumulative stomatal flux of NO, $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ ， $\mathrm { S O } _ { 2 }$ and $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ was （204号 $1 0 0 . 1 9 { \scriptstyle \pm 3 . 7 6 }$ ，510.68±24.78， 748.59±52.81 and $1 5 1 . 9 8 { \pm } 9 . 3 3 \quad \mathrm { m g } \cdot \mathrm { m } ^ { - 2 } { \cdot } \mathrm { a } ^ { - 1 } .$ respectively. These trace gases had not yet reached the injury level, except for $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ Nevertheless， whether the present $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ concentration negatively affected the vegetation requires further research because of the diverse sensitivity of different tree species to $\mathrm { N O } _ { 2 }$ . The inconsistent results of the AOT40 and $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } } 1 . 6$ , namely the AOT40 was above the critical level whereas the $\mathrm { A F _ { s t } } 1 . 6$ was below the critical level, suggested that the flux-based measurement was better suited for evaluating the risk of $\mathrm { O } _ { 3 }$ effects than the exposure-based method. When we focus on the foliar uptake of trace gases, the effect of these gases on the vegetation in turn should be considered, particularly for regions with serious air pollution problems.
